items.title: U.S. forces board Venezuela-linked sanctioned oil tanker in North Atlantic: U.S. officials
items.summary_auto: A U.S. official says U.S. forces have boarded a Venezuela-linked sanctioned oil tanker in North Atlantic after pursuing it for weeks.

items.title: Top European foreign ministers to meet after White House renews Greenland threats
items.summary_auto: European governments including those in France and Germany are working closely on a plan on how to respond should the United States act on its threat to take over Greenland, as Europe seeks to address U.S. President Donald Trump's ambitions in the region.

items.title: Warner Bros. rejects revised Paramount bid as risky leveraged buyout
items.summary_auto: Warner Bros. Discovery's board has unanimously turned down Paramount Skydance's latest attempt to acquire the studio, saying its revised $108.4-billion US hostile bid amounted to a risky leveraged buyout that investors should reject.

items.title: An unusually severe flu season is pushing hospitals in northeastern Ontario beyond capacity
No Yukon Quest sled dog race this year, say former board members
items.summary_auto: Mushers and former board members say the Yukon Quest is cancelled this year, because there is no one left to organize the iconic sled dog race.

items.title: The world's biggest risks, with Gerry Butts
items.summary_auto: A top adviser to two Canadian prime ministers outlines the risky global landscape, from zombie trade deals to a new American 'revolution.'

items.title: Former Manitoba PC leadership candidate sues province to restore Churchill-area polar bear viewing permits
items.summary_auto: A former Manitoba Progressive Conservative Party leadership candidate is suing the province, two wildlife officials and three NDP cabinet ministers for preventing his ecotourism company from operating offroad polar bear viewing vehicles east of Churchill.

items.title: GTA home sales fell 11.2% last year compared to 2024, report says
items.summary_auto: Home sales dropped 11.2 per cent in the Greater Toronto Area last year compared to that of 2024, according to a new report released Wednesday.

items.title: MUN's campus radio station is hoping to adapt amid financial troubles
items.summary_auto: Memorial University's campus radio station has been broadcasting in St. John's for 50 years. But as students turn away from traditional media, the non-profit station is encountering financial problems. As a result, station manager Rhea Rollmann says they're now shifting focus.

items.title: Canadian tourists voice concerns over Caribbean travel after U.S. strike on Venezuela
items.summary_auto: Travellers planning trips to the Caribbean are voicing trepidation online after the U.S. strike on Venezuela that captured president Nicolás Maduro, while one Latin America expert says it's not a good time to travel to the region.

items.title: Why Heated Rivalry's Team Canada fleece is taking the internet by storm
items.summary_auto: Desire for a Heated Rivalry-inspired Team Canada fleece came to a head recently after eagle-eyed fans spotted — and gushed over — a particular outfit choice by character Shane Hollander. And they've been demanding the opportunity to buy it ever since.

items.title: Ontario government call for Toronto police to crack down on protests puts free expression at risk: expert
items.summary_auto: An expert in free expression feels Ontario’s solicitor general is attempting to pressure Toronto police to change how they handle protests for political reasons. This comes after Solicitor General Michael Kerzner issued a letter to the Toronto Police Service, calling out what he described as a lack of enforcement for hate, intimidation and harassment-motivated offences at protests in the city.

items.title: 'Death ball' sponge, tiny opossum among cool new species of 2025
items.summary_auto: A spider with extraordinary genitalia, a carnivorous caterpillar that wears its prey's body parts, and a tiny opossum are among the cool new species described by science in 2025.

items.title: Turbulence is getting worse. Would it be better if planes looked more like birds?
items.summary_auto: Pilots can’t see it coming, and it’s hard to avoid. But severe clear-air turbulence can shake a plane ‘like King Kong.’ It’s on the rise, and forecast to get worse due to climate change. The rise has researchers investigating how to better predict clear-air turbulence, and looking to the physics of birds to make this chaotic force less dangerous.

items.title: Cornwall shooting sheds light on intimate partner violence among seniors, shelter says
items.summary_auto: A fatal weekend shooting in Cornwall, Ont., is shedding a stark spotlight on a segment of the population whose experience of intimate partner violence has only recently been recognized for what it is, a local women's shelter says.

items.title: Couple to wed at on-ice ceremony at Windsor Spitfires game
items.summary_auto: Some people can get sentimental about OHL hockey — but Sheldon Cadotte and Daylene Trudell are making it part of their romantic history. They're getting married on the ice during a game at the WFCU Centre on Jan. 8.

items.title: The U.S. imposed a blockade on sanctioned oil tankers tied to Venezuela. How is that working out?
items.summary_auto: Questioned over the weekend about how the U.S. government will take over governing Venezuela, Secretary of State Marco Rubio instead shifted the focus to the U.S. blockade of sanctioned oil tankers. CBC News looks at the origins of the blockade, what it entails, whether it's considered legal and just how effective it is.

items.title: Why everyone is talking about Heated Rivalry's Team Canada fleece
items.summary_auto: Desire for a Heated Rivalry-inspired Team Canada fleece came to a head recently after eagle-eyed fans spotted — and gushed over — a particular outfit choice by character Shane Hollander. And they've been demanding the opportunity to buy it ever since.

items.title: Inuvik residents asked to cut energy use because of low propane supply
items.summary_auto: People in Inuvik, N.W.T., are being asked to turn down the heat at home and also find other ways to reduce their energy use, because of a limited propane supply in town.

items.title: Why the discovery of hot gas between galaxies is exciting Canadian researchers
items.summary_auto: A team of international researchers, led by a University of British Columbia astrophysicist, has discovered a young galaxy cluster that was producing hot gas at a rate five times hotter than previously theoretically thought possible.

items.title: Lego unveils new ‘smart bricks’ with interactive lights and sounds
items.summary_auto: Lego has unveiled new high-tech “smart bricks” it says will bring its classic toys to life with lights, sound and interactive movement. But one expert on early learning says the innovation may lessen the potential for imagination that makes Lego a good toy for children’s development.

items.title: Aldrich Ames, CIA agent who spied for Moscow for almost a decade, dead at 84
items.summary_auto: CIA turncoat Aldrich Ames, who betrayed Western intelligence assets to the Soviet Union and Russia in one of the most damaging intelligence breaches in U.S. history, has died in a Maryland prison. He was 84.

items.title: Military 'always an option' to achieve Trump's goal of controlling Greenland, White House says
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump and his team are discussing various options for acquiring Greenland, including buying it, but the use of the U.S. military in furthering that goal is "always an option," the White House said on Tuesday.

items.title: Calgary restaurant owners jailed for financial abuse of temporary foreign workers
items.summary_auto: Manikandan Kasinathan, Chandramohan Marjak and Mary Roche, who co-owned Marina Dosa and Tandoori Grill, were each sentenced to 90-day jail terms after they were convicted of fraud over $5,000. They must also pay back the $44,000 they stole from three employees.

items.title: 28 years later, see the southern Quebec ice storm as it was reported in 1998
items.summary_auto: In one of the most important meteorological events in the province’s history, successive bouts of freezing rain left thick layers of ice over everything in southern Quebec during a week-long span in January 1998, knocking out power for millions of people.

items.title: 28 years later, see the ice storm as it was reported in 1998
items.summary_auto: In one of the most important meteorological events in the province’s history, successive bouts of freezing rain left thick layers of ice over everything in southern Quebec during a week-long span in January 1998, knocking out power for millions of people.

items.title: Man who killed Brown University students and MIT professor left behind recordings
items.summary_auto: The man identified by law enforcement as the shooter who killed two Brown University students and an MIT professor recorded videos saying he had been planning the attack for at least six semesters, according to information released Tuesday by the U.S. Department of Justice.

items.title: Greenlandic politician who fought for his people's autonomy wants U.S. to back off
items.summary_auto: "We have a very serious problem, and we need Canada's support," says Aqqaluk Lynge, a former member of Greenland's parliament and co-founder of the pro-Greenlandic independence party Inuit Ataqatigiit.

items.title: B.C. premier announces trade mission to India amid political tensions
items.summary_auto: B.C. Premier David Eby and Jobs Minister Ravi Kahlon are headed to India in less than a week on a trade mission to promote local businesses and industries. Their visit comes amid a backdrop of political uncertainty and tense international relations.

items.title: Nicole Kidman and Keith Urban officially divorced after 19-year marriage
items.summary_auto: Oscar-winning actor Nicole Kidman and Grammy-winning country singer Keith Urban have officially ended their marriage.

items.title: Men await sentencing for stabbing after neither was proven to be holding knife
items.summary_auto: What happens when two people are convicted of stabbing a man, but neither was proven to be holding the knife? When it comes to sentencing, it turns out, the judge has to treat each of them as though the other was the stabber.

items.title: His parents ran a beloved tavern there for decades, but the local fire chief couldn't save it
items.summary_auto: The historic building that housed the Douglas Tavern in tiny Douglas, Ont., burned to the ground overnight. Fire Chief Bill McHale's parents ran the popular gathering place for nearly half a century.

items.title: Coalition's Ukraine security guarantees include deploying troops if ceasefire is reached
items.summary_auto: After almost four years of major conflict, Ukraine has been given a series of concrete security guarantees — backed by more than 30 countries including Canada — that it can take into possible peace talks with Russia.

items.title: A new Grammy category honours album covers and the artists that make them
items.summary_auto: The Grammy award for best album cover will be awarded this year for the first time in over 50 years. Photographers and organizers say it couldn't have come soon enough.

items.title: What did Jack Ryan know about Venezuela? Spy show hero goes viral after Maduro capture
items.summary_auto: On the heels of the U.S. military attacks on Venezuela's capital over the weekend and the capture of president Nicolás Maduro, millions of people on social media are sharing a fictitious CIA analyst's insights on the South American petrostate.

items.title: Cuba discloses names of 32 military officers killed in U.S. action in Venezuela
items.summary_auto: The names, ranks and ages of the 32 Cuban military personnel killed during the capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro by U.S. forces were published Tuesday by the Cuban government, which announced two days of mourning.

items.title: Kashechewan First Nation residents in Ontario using bottled, river water after treatment plant fails
items.summary_auto: Kashechewan First Nation, along northern Ontario’s James Bay coast, is in a local state of emergency and plans to evacuate residents in the coming days because its water treatment system is in disrepair.

items.title: Israel clears final hurdle to start constructing controversial West Bank settlement project
items.summary_auto: Israel has cleared the final hurdle before starting construction on a contentious settlement project near Jerusalem that would effectively cut the occupied West Bank in two, according to a government tender.

items.title: Texas school shooting trial interrupted on Day 1 over dispute about witness testimony
items.summary_auto: The first day of the trial of a police officer who responded to the 2022 shooting at a Texas elementary school that killed 19 students and two teachers was interrupted on Tuesday after a witness provided testimony not previously presented to the defence.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Tech highlights from CES 2026
items.summary_auto: Companies both large and small are giving the public a first look at their new products during CES 2026, the world's largest consumer technology trade show, now underway in Las Vegas.

items.title: Air Transat pilots vote to ratify new five-year deal
items.summary_auto: 91 per cent of Air Transat pilots who voted agreed to ratify a new five-year employment contract with the airline. The union and company reached the tentative deal in December, narrowly avoiding a strike.
